content:
Let Bool\sf BoolBool be the category with objects being the natural numbers and morphisms n→mn\to mn→m being functions 2n→2m2^n \to 2^m2n→2m .
There is a forgetful functor 2(_):Bool→FinSet2^{(\_)}:{\sf Bool}\to {\sf FinSet}2(_):Bool→FinSet, which takes Boolean functions n→mn\to mn→m, to their underlying functions.
Conversely there exists a semifunctor, ie a functor not preserving identities ⌈log⁡2(_)⌉:FinSet→Bool\lceil \log_2 (\_)\rceil:{\sf FinSet}\to {\sf Bool}⌈log2​(_)⌉:FinSet→Bool, taking functions n→mn\to mn→m to their encodings of Boolean functions ⌈log⁡2n⌉→⌈log⁡2m⌉\lceil \log_2 n \rceil \to \lceil \log_2 m \rceil⌈log2​n⌉→⌈log2​m⌉ padded with 000 s (where 0↦00 \mapsto 00↦0).

Fix some nnn, then there is a function ηn:n↣2⌈log⁡2n⌉\eta_n:n \rightarrowtail 2^{\lceil \log_2 n \rceil}ηn​:n↣2⌈log2​n⌉. Moreover, for any mmm, and function f:n→2mf:n\to 2^mf:n→2m there exists a Boolean function g:⌈log⁡2n⌉→mg:\lceil \log_2 n \rceil\to mg:⌈log2​n⌉→m such that n→ηn2⌈log⁡2n⌉→2g2mn \xrightarrow{\eta_n} 2^{\lceil \log_2 n \rceil} \xrightarrow{2^g} 2^mnηn​​2⌈log2​n⌉2g​2m is equal to fff.

This looks a lot like the triangle for the unit of an adjunction, although the map ggg is not unique and ⌈log⁡2(_)⌉\lceil \log_2 (\_)\rceil⌈log2​(_)⌉ is not a functor.

Does anyone know what is going on here? Is there any way in which 2(_)2^{(\_)}2(_) can be seen to be right adjoint to ⌈log⁡2(_)⌉\lceil \log_2 (\_)\rceil⌈log2​(_)⌉?
How is ⌈log⁡2(_)⌉\lceil \log_2 (\_)\rceil⌈log2​(_)⌉ defined? I'm not sure what you mean by "encodings of Boolean functions"
Good question! I didn't get it either, but I wasn't brave enough to ask.

I guess I am working in FinOrd, the skeleton of Finset and we have to fix an order the on the points of all the objects beforehand.
Take any function f:n→mf:n \to mf:n→m. Then to each point 1→n1\to n1→n, we can assign a natural number 0≤i<n0 \leq i < n0≤i<n corresponding to the position in the order.
So this number can be encoded in binary, as an element of 2⌈log⁡2n⌉2^{\lceil \log_2 n \rceil}2⌈log2​n⌉ , left-padding with 000 s when necessary.
Similarly, each f(i)f(i)f(i) also can be encoded in Binary in same way. So you get a function of type 2⌈log⁡2n⌉→2⌈log⁡2m⌉ 2^{\lceil \log_2 n \rceil} \to 2^{\lceil \log_2 m \rceil}2⌈log2​n⌉→2⌈log2​m⌉, or equivalently a Boolean function ⌈log⁡2n⌉→⌈log⁡2m⌉ \lceil \log_2 n \rceil \to \lceil \log_2 m \rceil⌈log2​n⌉→⌈log2​m⌉ sending all the unaccoutned for points just to the string of 000 s.

I'm not sure I understand what the category Bool\mathsf{Bool}Bool is, so I may as well expose my ignorance, and hopefully help others understand what's going on by way of concrete example.

It sounds like a Homset, say, HomBool(3,5)\mathrm{Hom}_\mathsf{Bool}(3,5)HomBool​(3,5) is isomorphic to the set of all functions from 3-digit binary numbers to 5-digit binary numbers. Then your forgetful functor 2(−):Bool→FinOrd2^{(-)} : \mathsf{Bool} \rightarrow \mathsf{FinOrd}2(−):Bool→FinOrd takes this HomBool(3,5)\mathrm{Hom}_\mathsf{Bool}(3,5)HomBool​(3,5) to HomFinOrd(8,32)\mathrm{Hom}_\mathsf{FinOrd}(8,32)HomFinOrd​(8,32).
If that guess is correct, then I further guess that ⌈log⁡2(−)⌉\lceil \log_2(-) \rceil⌈log2​(−)⌉ would "promote" HomFinOrd(3,5)\mathrm{Hom}_\mathsf{FinOrd}(3,5)HomFinOrd​(3,5) to HomFinOrd(4,8)\mathrm{Hom}_\mathsf{FinOrd}(4,8)HomFinOrd​(4,8), and interpret it as HomBool(2,3)\mathrm{Hom}_\mathsf{Bool}(2,3)HomBool​(2,3).

Assuming I am right so far, let's consider the function ηn\eta_nηn​ in FinOrd\mathsf{FinOrd}FinOrd for some example value of nnn. Let's take n=6n=6n=6. Then η6:6↣8\eta_6 : 6 \rightarrowtail 8η6​:6↣8. I'm assuming this takes i6i_6i6​ to i8i_8i8​ for each iii from 0 to 5. This looks to me like what the "promotion" I just mentioned should act. Am I on target with your setup so far?

I don't know what this is called, but here's one thing I can contribute. A functor U:D→CU:D\to CU:D→C is a right adjoint iff for all d∈Dd\in Dd∈D, the comma category d/Ud/Ud/U has an initial object. In your case, for each n∈FinSetn\in \mathsf{FinSet}n∈FinSet, the comma category n/2(−)n/2^{(-)}n/2(−) has a weakly initial object. So maybe this could be called some sort of "weak adjunction"?
@Jason Erbele all that you've wrote is concordant with my understanding. If Cole says it's not right, then I'm also mistaken.
Thanks for explaining that stuff, @Cole Comfort.

My understanding is that 2(−)2^{(-)}2(−) is a full and faithful functor, basically embedding Bool\mathsf{Bool}Bool as a full subcategory of FinSet\mathsf{FinSet}FinSet. Bool\mathsf{Bool}Bool is not what I normally think of as Bool, as the morphisms don't have to respect the Boolean algebra structure of objects, they are just any functions whatsoever. One way I am thinking of this is that a morphism is anything you can do with logic gates. Although this category doesn't adhere to the standard aesthetic "morphisms should preserve structure", I still care about it because it is how computers store natural numbers and maps between them. This adjunction seems to have relevance in that same context --- going back and forth between a computer representation of natural numbers and maps between them, and the "concepts themselves".

Yes: both the names Bool\mathsf{Bool}Bool and FinOrd\mathsf{FinOrd}FinOrd as used above confuse the heck out of me. I'd use Bool\mathsf{Bool}Bool either to mean the category of boolean algebras or the category of booleans, the two-element poset with 0≤10 \le 10≤1. I'd use FinOrd\mathsf{FinOrd}FinOrd to mean the category of finite ordinals and order-preserving maps... well, actually I'd use Δ+\Delta_+Δ+​ and call it the augmented simplex category, but Wikipedia actually suggests calling it FinOrd\mathsf{FinOrd}FinOrd.
Yeah I suppose I could have chosen better names to avoid confusion.
But complaining about notation is the past-time of the category theorist... and right now I'm just lying in bed drinking in coffee, waking up and complaining about notation.
Also, I admit this seems very contrived, but it came up and I need to use it
Here's another example of weird "semi-adjunction"

What's a "semi-adjunction", again?

I occasionally people if they've thought about things like adjunctions where instead of a natural isomorphism of homsets hom(Lx,y) ≅\cong≅ hom(x,Ry) there's just a natural transformation. But that may be some other kind of "semi-adjunction".
It doesn't have any existing definition that I know of, that's why it's in quotes. I just mean something that's kind of like an adjunction but not quite
Oh, that's the kind I'm thinking of! Where the natural transformation is not iso
Oh, cool! There should be two fundamentally different kinds, depending on which way the natural transformation goes: from left to right, or from right to left.
Which kind do you have? (There should be different intuitions for the different kinds, but I don't have any intuition for either.)
Well in this case it is none of the above because ⌈log⁡2(_)⌉\lceil \log_2 (\_)\rceil⌈log2​(_)⌉ preserves composition, but not identities, so it is not a functor.

Sorry I'm not being clear. I'm saying that this topic and the one I linked to are both examples of things that are similar to adjunctions but are not adjunctions. The one I linked to is where the natural transformation is not iso. But what makes the construction in this topic not an adjunction is something else: that the corresponding universal property is only weak, as elaborated here
I guess that this really isn't truly a comma category either, because the lack of being a functor. So it is even worse!

Joshua Meyers said:

It doesn't have any existing definition that I know of, that's why it's in quotes. I just mean something that's kind of like an adjunction but not quite

This is known as a weak adjunction. See for instance Kainen's Weak adjoint functors or, more recently, Lack–Rosický's Enriched weakness. The concept appears to be missing an nLab page.
Instead of asking for a natural isomorphism of hom-sets, one asks for a natural surjection.
I think this is actually a "weak semiadjunction" if that even is a meaningful thing to say
It certainly is, though I'm not sure anyone has formally considered them before.
(I didn't spot the comments above about not preserving identities.)
I mean, maybe the triangle equations are no longer equivalent to the hom set definition
And who is to say which is the right definition
The right definition is the one that fits your examples ;)
